materials: Six bottles per group of four students

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and select the correct foods.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Read clues aloud: “It’s yellow. You use it on bread.” Students guess: “It’s butter!” Do this as a game where teams earn points.
stretchStrategies: Students play “Fridge Mystery Game” in teams. One student secretly chooses 3 foods for their fridge and describes them with hints. Others guess and write: “He’s got some ___.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write about what their friends have in their fridges using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Model: “My friend has some grapes and some cheese in her fridge.” Students write about their own friend’s imaginary fridge using the same structure.
stretchStrategies: Students play “Fridge Mystery Game” in teams. One student secretly chooses 3 foods for their fridge and describes them with hints. Others guess and write: “He’s got some ___.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can present what their friends have in their fridges to the class using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Presentation) Students create a mini poster with a fridge picture and list 4–5 foods inside. Present using full sentences.

items: Food in syllabi typically Western-centric: banh mi >> bread
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
